title: License
text: R package (yusufHAIGermany) released MIT License. included data (sim_monthly, sim_weekly, sim_daily) synthetic derivatives publicly available data European Centre Disease Prevention Control (ECDC) Point Prevalence Survey Healthcare-Associated Infections Antimicrobial Use European Acute Care Hospitals, 2011–2012. Original data © European Centre Disease Prevention Control (ECDC), 2013. Licensed Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC 4.0). See https://creativecommons.org/licenses//4.0/ details. simulation transformation code used generate synthetic datasets (data-raw/simulate_hai_germany.R) © 2025 Yusuf Romadhon licensed MIT License.

title: Examples: Interactive Time Series
text: Animated totals infection type. Use play controls step period.
code:
monthly_long <- sim_monthly |> mutate(frame = format(as.Date(date), "%b %Y")) |> select(date, frame, hai, cases_month) plot_ly( monthly_long, x = ~hai, y = ~cases_month, frame = ~frame, type = "bar", color = ~hai, hovertemplate = paste( "%{frame}
%{x}: %{y:,.0f} cases") ) |> layout( xaxis = list(title = ""), yaxis = list(title = "Cases (monthly)"), updatemenus = list( list(type = "buttons", buttons = list( list(method = "animate", args = list(NULL, list(mode = "immediate", fromcurrent = TRUE)), label = "Play"), list(method = "animate", args = list(NULL, list(mode = "immediate", frame = list(duration = 0), transition = list(duration = 0))), label = "Pause") ), pad = list(r = 10, t = 70), x = 0.1, xanchor = "left", y = 0, yanchor = "top") ) )

title: Examples: Interactive Time Series
text: Cases per week infection type. Tooltip shows exact values.
code:
wk <- sim_weekly |> mutate(week = iso_week, yr = year(as.Date(date))) |> group_by(yr, week, hai) |> summarise(cases = sum(cases_week), .groups = "drop") plot_ly( wk, x = ~week, y = ~hai, z = ~cases, type = "heatmap", hovertemplate = "W%{x} — %{y}
%{z:,.0f} cases" ) |> layout(xaxis = list(title = "ISO week"), yaxis = list(title = ""))

title: Examples: Interactive Time Series
text: Small multiples one chart per metric.
code: daily_cases <- sim_daily |>   group_by(date, hai) |>   summarise(value = sum(cases_day), .groups = "drop") |>   arrange(date)  daily_deaths <- sim_daily |>   group_by(date, hai) |>   summarise(value = sum(deaths_day), .groups = "drop") |>   arrange(date)  daily_dalys <- sim_daily |>   group_by(date, hai) |>   summarise(value = sum(dalys_day), .groups = "drop") |>   arrange(date)  subplot(   plot_ly(daily_cases, x = ~date, y = ~value,            color = ~hai, type = "scatter", mode = "lines") |>     layout(yaxis = list(title = "Cases"), xaxis = list(title = "")),   plot_ly(daily_deaths, x = ~date, y = ~value, color = ~hai, type = "scatter", mode = "lines") |>     layout(yaxis = list(title = "Deaths"), xaxis = list(title = "")),   plot_ly(daily_dalys, x = ~date, y = ~value, color = ~hai, type = "scatter", mode = "lines") |>     layout(yaxis = list(title = "DALYs"), xaxis = list(title = "Date")),   nrows = 3, shareX = TRUE, titleY = TRUE   ) |>    layout(showlegend = TRUE)

title: Examples: Interactive Time Series
Get Started with yusufHAIGermany
text: vignette gives short tour package datasets shows make quick, interactive checks. package provides three simulation tables HAIs Germany (2011 – 2012): sim_monthly: columns date, year, month, hai, cases_month, deaths_month, dalys_month sim_weekly: columns date, year, iso_week, hai, cases_week, deaths_week, dalys_week sim_daily: columns date, year, yday, wday, hai, cases_day, deaths_day, dalys_day

title: Get Started with yusufHAIGermany
Get Started with yusufHAIGermany
code: p_month <- sim_monthly |>   mutate(month_lab = format(as.Date(date), "%b %Y")) |>   group_by(date, hai) |>   summarise(cases = sum(cases_month), .groups = "drop") |>   arrange(date) |>   plot_ly(x = ~date, y = ~cases,            color = ~hai, type = "scatter",            mode = "lines",           hovertemplate = paste("%{x|%b %Y}",                                 "%{fullData.name}: %{y:,.0f} cases")           ) |>   layout(     yaxis = list(title = "Cases (monthly)"),     xaxis = list(title = "Date") )  p_month

title: Get Started with yusufHAIGermany
code: top_tbl <- sim_monthly |>   group_by(date, hai) |>   summarise(cases = sum(cases_month), .groups = "drop") |>   group_by(date) |>   slice_max(order_by = cases, n = 1, with_ties = FALSE) |>   ungroup() |>   arrange(date)  top_tbl ## # A tibble: 24 × 3 ##    date       hai   cases ##    <date>     <chr> <int> ##  1 2011-01-01 UTI   42941 ##  2 2011-02-01 UTI   45245 ##  3 2011-03-01 UTI   41143 ##  4 2011-04-01 UTI   44316 ##  5 2011-05-01 UTI   44266 ##  6 2011-06-01 UTI   42741 ##  7 2011-07-01 UTI   41775 ##  8 2011-08-01 UTI   40444 ##  9 2011-09-01 UTI   31023 ## 10 2011-10-01 UTI   36553 ## # ℹ 14 more rows

title: Get Started with yusufHAIGermany
code: annual <- sim_monthly |>   mutate(yr = year(as.Date(date))) |>   group_by(yr) |>   summarise(     cases = sum(cases_month),     deaths = sum(deaths_month),     dalys = sum(dalys_month),     .groups = "drop"     )  annual ## # A tibble: 2 × 4 ##      yr   cases deaths   dalys ##   <dbl>   <int>  <int>   <dbl> ## 1  2011 1030688  33692 523173. ## 2  2012 1016998  33611 521041.

title: Analysis of Germany HAI Burden (German PPS) with Shiny Explorer
text: yusufHAIGermany R package offers reproducible simulation visualisation framework examining Healthcare-Associated Infections (HAIs) Germany. inspired Eurosurveillance study Zacher et al. (2019).“Application new methodology R package reveals high burden healthcare-associated infections (HAI) Germany compared average European Union/European Economic Area, 2011 – 2012.” package generates daily, weekly, monthly simulated datasets calibrated 2011 – 2012 ECDC PPS (Point Prevalence Survey) data.

title: Analysis of Germany HAI Burden (German PPS) with Shiny Explorer

title: Analysis of Germany HAI Burden (German PPS) with Shiny Explorer
text: simulations introduce mild seasonality random variation reflect uncertainty real-world HAI burdens.

title: Analysis of Germany HAI Burden (German PPS) with Shiny Explorer

(2019).Application new methodology R package reveals high burden healthcare-associated infections (HAI) Germany compared average European Union/European Economic Area, 2011–2012.Eurosurveillance, 24(46). https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2019.24.46.1900135 Data licensed Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 (CC 4.0).

Simulated German HAI daily series, 2011–2012 — sim_daily
text: tibble columns: date Date year Integer year yday Day--year (1–366) wday Day--week (1=Mon, 7=Sun) hai Character infection type cases_day Integer simulated cases deaths_day Integer simulated deaths dalys_day Numeric simulated DALYs
